newsitem.title: USA: California $1.2 bln rail project wins federal OK.
newsitem.headline: California $1.2 bln rail project wins federal OK.

text.p: The Bay Area Rapid Transit (BART) District said on Tuesday the environmental impact report for a $1.2 billion transit project in northern California had received federal approval.

BART Board President Dan Richard said the transit district has received the so-called "record of decision" from the Federal Transit Administration, completing the federal environmental process for the massive project.
"This is very exciting news because it represents achieving a critical milestone in moving the project forward and securing a full funding agreement from the federal government," Richard said.

The project calls for building an 8.2 mile rail extension to improve transportation to the San Francisco International Airport. The total project cost is estimated to be $1.167 billion, including $750 million in federal funds.
Under the plan, the airport would provide $200 million, the state some $108 million and the San Mateo County Transit District about $99 million.
The next major step will be the issuance of a full funding grant agreement by the Federal Transit Administration, expected this fall, Richard said.
"At that point we are truly out of the starting gate and the next thing will be to break ground," Richard said.
The extension is expected to be completed by the year 2000.
